title: Where to find the best food under $20 in Waltham
author: Katelyn Umholtz and Abby Patkin
bullets: Taqueria El Amigo and Carl's Steak Subs offer popular budget-friendly meals in Waltham under $20.
Domenic's and Boston Kebab provide affordable, sizeable portions such as paninis and kebab roll-ups.
Guanachapi's Mexican and Latin Food and Joe Sent Me serve varied dishes at reasonable prices on Moody Street.

title: Turning 40 made her discover running. Ten years later, she’s running Boston.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Melissa Rousselle, 50, from Haverhill, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for Rebekah's Angels Foundation.
Rousselle discovered running at 40, which helped her manage lifelong depression and anxiety.
Rebekah’s Angels Foundation supports trauma-affected children and families, aligning with Rousselle's personal journey.

title: For $3 million, a Newton ‘painted lady’ with plenty of whimsy
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: The historic Charles Davis House at 929 Beacon St., Newton, is listed for $2,995,000.
Constructed in 1860, the house features six bedrooms, eight-and-a-half bathrooms, and modern amenities.
Unique design elements include vibrant colors, stained windows, a mansard roof, and a veranda.

title: Could Brian Thomas Jr. be a legitimate trade target for Patriots this offseason?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots may target Brian Thomas Jr. after his 1,200-yard season with Jaguars despite his 2025 performance decline.
Stefon Diggs' future with Patriots uncertain, leaving potential market for Thomas as New England seeks roster upgrades.
Thomas' potential trade value could require the Patriots to offer multiple draft picks and possibly a young player.

title: 3 takeaways from Team USA men’s hockey’s OT win over Sweden in Olympics
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Quinn Hughes scored the overtime winner for Team USA, defeating Sweden 2-1 in the Olympic quarterfinals.
Team USA, featuring Bruins' Quinn Hughes and Charlie McAvoy, advanced to the semifinals against Slovakia on Friday.
Four Bruins players remain in medal contention, including Team USA's McAvoy and Finland's Henri Jokiharju.

title: Pittsfield armored vehicle company is largest ICE contract in Mass.
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Lenco Industries in Pittsfield secured $5.2 million in ICE contracts, becoming Massachusetts' largest ICE contractor.
Governor Maura Healey opposes state resources supporting ICE, while Lenco continues contracts with federal agencies.
Lenco also refused an additional $10 million ICE contract, citing other business developments with military and emergency services.

title: Former State Police union head, lobbyist get more prison time for fraud, racketeering
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Former Massachusetts State Police union president Dana Pullman sentenced to two years in prison for fraud and racketeering.
Lobbyist Anne Lynch sentenced to 15 months for fraud-related crimes; both ordered to pay over $40,000 restitution each.
Court reversed some wire fraud convictions; remaining charges include racketeering and tax crimes, according to prosecutors.

title: Boston 25 News head meteorologist Kevin Lemanowicz departing after 3 decades with the station
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Kevin Lemanowicz, chief meteorologist at Boston 25, will step down on February 27 after nearly 30 years.
Lemanowicz joined Boston 25 at its inception in 1996, providing weather updates through significant New England storms.
Boston 25 praised Lemanowicz for his accurate forecasts and strong community connections over his decades-long career.

title: Red Sox release statement after outcry over flawed jersey design
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Boston Red Sox announced revised 2026 home jerseys will be ready by Opening Day following fan backlash over design flaws.
Initial jerseys featured overlapping 'RED' and 'SOX' stitching with red striping, prompting the design adjustments with MLB and Fanatics.
The team emphasized that the original design was their decision and commended Fanatics for their support and timely jersey alteration.

title: Pawtucket police find firearms in ice rink shooter’s storage locker, identify ‘courageous citizens’ who intervened
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Pawtucket police found firearms and ammunition in a storage unit belonging to the ice rink shooter, Robert Dorgan.
Dorgan, 56, killed his ex-wife and son at a Pawtucket ice rink; police identified him as the shooter.
Civilians intervened during the attack; several remain hospitalized in critical condition, police corroborated.
